newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Budapest gang war bomb-supply suspects held.
newsitem.headline: Budapest gang war bomb-supply suspects held.

text.p: Police said on Friday they had detained two men suspected of selling hand grenades used in a spate of bombings in Budapest in the past two months.
The Hungarian capital's police chief, Janos Bodracska, told a news conference that the men had been held on Thursday night after being found in possession of 28 grenades and other explosives.
Budapest has been rocked since September by a gangland turf war that has seen more than a dozen hand grenade attacks on nightclubs and restaurants and at least four shootings, one of them fatal.
The latest attack was on Friday when an unidentified assailant first shot at a 52-year-old Budapest casino owner and then struck him with the gun before fleeing.

Bodracska said the two men held on Thursday had admitted selling nine handgrenades. Police were now conducting searches which have already unearthed a Stinger rocket in a house in a village in southwest Hungary.
The police chief added that the black-market price of a hand grenade was currently 10,000 forints ($60) in Budapest.
The gangland war began over a sum of 2.7 billion forints, borrowed by an underworld figure at high interest, Bodracska said.
"He used the money and the sum was dwindling, and when it got too low, he disappered," Bodracska said. "Now we cannot find him and (the gangs) can't either."
He said the only casualties of the gang war had been criminals but that the property of ordinary citizens, such as cars, had been damaged. ($1=161.31 Forint)
